metadata.sermon_title: Footnote to a Harsh, Hot Wind
metadata.sermon_start_end: These words from the prophet Jeremiah are hard words for 9/11. A hot wind comes from me out of the bare heights in the desert toward my poor people. (v. 11) As you know, I did not pick these verses; they were given to me [...] The footnote comes at the end of the poem. It is a hard word with a footnote that we may receive in wisdom against all the foolishness around us. Jeremiah sees that there are very many foolish people. God is on the lookout for a few wise people who will make an effective difference.
metadata.notes: The sermon utilizes the 9/11 anniversary as a thematic backdrop for interpreting the lectionary texts.

phase_1_concrete_experience.analysis: The sermon connects with concrete experience primarily through the historical trauma of 9/11 and the imagery of environmental decay. However, it lacks a specific, localized narrative of a contemporary individual's life. The 'experience' is largely collective and historical rather than personal and immediate. It succeeds in evoking the 'feeling' of being out of control, but remains somewhat detached by focusing on 'poetry' as the medium of experience.
quotes: It felt, in ancient Jerusalem, like the coming down of the Twin Towers.
The poetry intends to terrify ancient Jerusalem as a wake-up call.
We can see the undoing of creation all around us.
strengths: Strong use of the 9/11 anniversary to ground the emotional weight of the text.
Effective use of sensory language (hot wind, birds gone) to evoke a sense of loss.
improvement_points: Include a specific contemporary anecdote to bridge the gap between 'ancient poetry' and the hearer's Monday morning.
Move beyond collective trauma to individual identification with the 'fool' or the 'wise'.
phase_1_concrete_experience.homiletical_manifestations: Hook in the introduction via the 9/11 date; use of apocalyptic imagery to create emotional resonance.

phase_2_reflective_observation.analysis: This phase is well-developed through the analysis of 'narcotization' and 'denial.' The preacher explores the human condition of being 'foolish'—defined here as living as if God does not exist, whether in arrogance or despair. It pauses to ask why the people of Jerusalem (and by extension, the modern hearer) do not notice the 'big trouble.' It offers a clear cultural critique of modern indifference.
quotes: The poetry is a wake-up call to ancient Jerusalem that had been narcoticized so that it did not notice the big trouble coming.
The fool can say in arrogance, 'There is no God.' Or the fool can say in despair, 'There is no God.' Either way... there is only us.
strengths: Insightful psychological analysis of denial as a response to crisis.
Clear articulation of the 'problem' (recalcitrance and indifference).
improvement_points: Provide more specific examples of modern 'narcotics' that prevent us from seeing the 'hot wind.'
Deepen the cultural analysis of why 'arrogance' and 'despair' are two sides of the same coin.
phase_2_reflective_observation.homiletical_manifestations: Problem analysis regarding human denial; exploration of the 'fool' archetype; cultural critique of modern security.

phase_3_abstract_conceptualization.analysis: The sermon offers a strong theological framework centered on the 'adversative conjunction'—the 'Yet' of God. It engages in solid exegesis of the Hebrew poetic structure ('I looked' four times) and the character of God as one who reverses field. It successfully connects the harshness of Jeremiah with the grace of the Gospel (lost sheep/coin). The 'big idea' is the persistence of God's presence beyond judgment.
quotes: Yet . . . the big adversative conjunction; Nevertheless! All of that notwithstanding!
It would not happen, so the ancient prophet affirms, apart from the reality of God.
The wise know, says the Psalmist, that God is with the 'righteous,' that is, with those who invest in the well-being of the community.
strengths: Clear theological focus on the sovereignty and mercy of God.
Effective synthesis of Old Testament judgment and New Testament grace.
improvement_points: The definition of 'righteous' as 'investing in the community' is slightly thin and could use more dogmatic grounding.
Explain the theological tension between God's 'fed up' state and the 'footnote' more deeply.
phase_3_abstract_conceptualization.homiletical_manifestations: Exegesis of Jeremiah 4; theological definition of 'wisdom' vs 'folly'; Christological connection to the parables of the lost.

phase_4_active_experimentation.analysis: This is the weakest phase. While the preacher mentions 'changed conduct' and 'changed policy,' these remain abstract categories. The call to 'notice' the poem is an internal cognitive act rather than a concrete 'experiment' in daily life. The sermon identifies what is 'not appropriate' (war on poor, violence) but offers few specific handles for what the hearer should actually *do* tomorrow.
quotes: What is appropriate is changed attitude, changed conduct, changed policy...
God is on the lookout for a few wise people who will make an effective difference.
What counts for more is that you get the poem, that you let it interrupt your life enough to notice.
strengths: Identifies broad ethical categories (peace, care for the poor).
Challenges the hearer to move beyond fear into hope.
improvement_points: Translate 'changed policy' into a concrete action step for a church member.
Define what an 'effective difference' looks like in a specific, local context.
phase_4_active_experimentation.homiletical_manifestations: General ethical calls; invitation to 'notice' and 'receive wisdom'; rejection of fear-based responses.

declarative_assimilating.preacher_role: The preacher acts as a theological philosopher, interpreting the 'logic' of the poem and the nature of God's 'Yet.'
declarative_assimilating.core_question_answered: It answers 'What is the truth?' by asserting that God is the ultimate reality behind both judgment and hope.
declarative_assimilating.analysis: The sermon follows a clear logical progression (I, II, III, IV) and uses rational categories like 'arrogance' and 'despair' to categorize the human condition.
quotes: The fool says in his heart, 'There is no God.' ... And the poet responds, 'Well there is God.'
improvement_points: Could be less reliant on the 'four-point' outline for a more organic flow.

pragmatic_converging.preacher_role: The preacher avoids the role of coach/guide, explicitly stating 'We cannot apply this text.'
pragmatic_converging.core_question_answered: The question 'How does it work?' is largely ignored in favor of 'How do we see?'
pragmatic_converging.analysis: There is a lack of step-by-step guidance. The preacher seems wary of 'tips and tricks' homiletics, which leaves the pragmatic hearer without a clear path.
quotes: We cannot 'apply' this text. We cannot read it as though it were contemporary...
improvement_points: Needs to provide 'practical wisdom' as defined by the Psalmist.

narrative_accommodating.preacher_role: The preacher acts as a literary critic/storyteller, walking the hearer through the 'plot' of the poem.
narrative_accommodating.core_question_answered: Answers 'What happens?' by describing the 'two waves' of trouble and the 'footnote' resolution.
narrative_accommodating.analysis: While not a first-person narrative, the sermon treats the biblical text as a dramatic movement with tension and resolution.
quotes: The big trouble coming... is in two waves.
But then, the poet slips in a little footnote.
strengths: Respects the dramatic movement of the text
improvement_points: Could use more contemporary narrative to ground the biblical drama.

visionary_diverging.preacher_role: The preacher excels as a poet/artist, using evocative language to paint the 'undoing of creation.'
visionary_diverging.core_question_answered: Answers 'Why is this important?' by showing the cosmic stakes of God's reality.
visionary_diverging.analysis: The sermon relies heavily on metaphors (hot wind, whirlwind, footnote) to awaken the hearer's imagination and longing for God's 'Yet.'
quotes: The light of sun and moon going out, the hills unsteady and tottering, the birds all gone...
We can be haunted by it. We can notice the hot wind blowing.
improvement_points: Ensure the 'vision' leads to a concrete 'response' so it doesn't remain merely aesthetic.

descriptive_empirical.priestly_listening: Listens to the collective trauma of 9/11 and the anxiety of environmental crisis.
descriptive_empirical.analysis: Identifies a state of 'narcotization' and 'denial' in the face of global threats.
quotes: The poetry is a wake-up call to ancient Jerusalem that had been narcoticized...
improvement_points: More specific 'listening' to the local congregation's specific struggles.

interpretive.wisdom_of_sage: Uses the concept of 'the fool' to interpret modern arrogance and despair.
interpretive.analysis: Explains 'why' people are in denial: because they imagine they are on their own (no God).
quotes: The fool can say in arrogance... or the fool can say in despair...
strengths: Deep psychological insight into despair as a form of atheism
improvement_points: Could integrate more sociological data on 'narcotization' in consumer culture.

normative.prophetic_discernment: Brings the 'adversative conjunction' of God's word to bear on the human condition.
normative.analysis: Clearly establishes that God's will is for 'well-being' and 'righteousness' rather than 'full end.'
quotes: 'Yet, I will not make a full end.' ... This is what the wise know.
improvement_points: None; this is the sermon's strongest task.

pragmatic.servant_leadership: Calls for 'changed policy' but provides no roadmap for the congregation to lead that change.
pragmatic.analysis: The response is framed as 'not being afraid,' which is a good start but lacks 'how-to' handles.
quotes: What is appropriate is changed attitude, changed conduct...
strengths: Clear call to reject fear-based politics
improvement_points: Suggest concrete ways the church can be a 'refuge for the poor' today.

assimilating_style.analysis: Highly effective for this style. The sermon provides a clear four-part structure and a logical theological argument.
assimilating_style.preferences_addressed: The use of the 'adversative conjunction' as a linguistic/theological model appeals to the rational mind.
assimilating_style.risks: The sermon risks being too 'literary' or 'abstract' for those who need immediate application.

converging_style.analysis: Poorly addressed. The preacher explicitly distances himself from 'applying' the text.
converging_style.preferences_addressed: The mention of 'changed policy' hints at utility but doesn't deliver.
converging_style.risks: The hearer may leave feeling they have heard a great lecture but have no idea what to do with it.

accommodating_style.analysis: Moderately addressed through the shared experience of 9/11.
accommodating_style.preferences_addressed: The 'feeling' of being out of control is well-articulated.
accommodating_style.risks: Lack of concrete action steps leaves the 'doing' preference of this style unfulfilled.

diverging_style.analysis: Highly effective. The sermon is rich in metaphor and invites multiple perspectives on the 'wind.'
diverging_style.preferences_addressed: The 'Visionary' role of the preacher provides the inspiration and 'why' this style craves.
diverging_style.risks: The sermon could be seen as too 'poetic' or 'vague' regarding the actual solution.

cycle_completeness.analysis: The sermon starts strong with Concrete Experience (9/11) and moves effectively through Reflective Observation and Abstract Conceptualization. However, the cycle stalls before reaching robust Active Experimentation.
missing_phases: Active Experimentation (Phase 4) is underdeveloped and lacks specificity.
cycle_completeness.sequence_and_flow: The flow is logical: Context (9/11) -> Text (Jeremiah's poetry) -> Problem (Folly/Denial) -> Solution (God's 'Yet') -> Call to Wisdom.

balance_between_phases.analysis: The sermon is heavily weighted toward the 'Diverging' and 'Assimilating' quadrants (Experience, Reflection, Conceptualization).
balance_between_phases.consequences: Hearers will be intellectually and emotionally stimulated but may lack the agency to act on their new insights.

homiletic_window_movement.analysis: Moves from Visionary (the wind) to Declarative (the truth of God) to Narrative (the movement of the poem). It fails to land in the Pragmatic window.
homiletic_window_movement.identified_structure: Visionary (9/11 imagery) -> Reflective (Folly/Arrogance) -> Declarative (Theology of 'Yet') -> Narrative (Gospel parables).
homiletic_window_movement.effectiveness: The movement is effective for 'opening' the hearer but less effective for 'equipping' them.

holistic_learning.analysis: Addresses the Head (theology) and Heart (poetry/fear) well. The 'Hands' (action) are neglected.
holistic_learning.epistemological_approach: Primarily experience-oriented truth through the lens of poetic imagination.

overall_picture.summary: The sermon is a strong example of visionary and theological preaching that fails to bridge the gap into concrete practice. It begins with a powerful connection to a collective trauma (9/11) and uses this to explore the biblical text's 'wild imagery.' The preacher effectively diagnoses the human condition as one of 'narcotized denial,' categorizing it into arrogance and despair. The theological 'big idea'—the 'Yet' of God—is clearly articulated and provides a robust foundation for hope. However, the sermon explicitly shies away from 'application,' which results in a truncated learning cycle. The 'Active Experimentation' phase is left to generalities like 'changed conduct' without specific guidance. This serves the 'Assimilating' and 'Diverging' learners well but leaves the 'Converging' and 'Accommodating' learners without a clear response.
strengths_top_5: Evocative use of imagery (hot wind, footnote) to make the text 'haunting.'
Clear theological distinction between the 'fool' (atheism of despair/arrogance) and the 'wise.'
Strong contextual grounding using the 9/11 anniversary.
Effective synthesis of the 'harsh' Jeremiah text with the 'welcoming' Gospel parables.
Logical four-part structure that is easy for the hearer to follow.
improvement_points_top_5: Develop concrete 'Active Experimentation' steps to move beyond 'noticing.'
Include contemporary personal narratives to complement the collective/apocalyptic imagery.
Clarify the pragmatic implications of 'changed policy' for a lay audience.
Bridge the gap between the 'ancient poem' and 'contemporary application' more courageously.
Define 'righteousness' and 'wisdom' with more practical, everyday examples.
excluded_learning_styles: Converging learners (who need practical utility) and Accommodating learners (who need to 'do' something) are underserved.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Strengthen the 'Active Experimentation' phase by asking: 'What is one specific thing a wise person does on Monday because of this 'Yet'?'
Use a contemporary 'slice of life' story in the introduction to increase identification.
Experiment with a more 'Pragmatic' structure to balance the 'Visionary' tendencies.
overall_picture.conclusion: This sermon is a high-quality theological and poetic reflection that succeeds in 'interrupting' the hearer's life with the reality of God. From a Kolb perspective, it is a 'top-heavy' sermon—strong on reflection and conceptualization but weak on application. The preacher's resistance to 'application' is a homiletical choice that preserves the 'wildness' of the text but at the cost of the hearer's practical transformation. To reach a score of 8 or higher, the sermon would need to translate its profound theological 'Yet' into the 'How' of daily discipleship. It remains a clear, effective, and sober analysis of the human condition under the judgment and grace of God.
